headline: Jewish people should eye Heritage Foundation's Project Esther | Opinion
context: You know who’s not worked up enough about antisemitism in the U.S.?

annotations.paragraph: Or so claims the Heritage Foundation, the folks who brought you Project 2025, the manifesto President Donald Trump and unelected edgelord Elon Musk are using to dismantle the federal government.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the Heritage Foundation's previous project, which is relevant to understanding their credibility and influence.

annotations.paragraph: Less well known is the conservative think tank’s other plan to reshape American society, Project Esther.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces Project Esther, which is directly relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Where Project 2025 is a blueprint for dismantling an American government its authors believe is corrupted by Marxism and wokeness, Project Esther is a plan to fight what it says is widespread, organized antisemitism (informed by Marxism, natch) dedicated to the destruction of capitalism and American democracy.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the purpose and goals of Project Esther, which is central to the article's topic.

annotations.paragraph: Abetted by “the dangerous complacency” of American Jews, the authors write, antisemitic supporters of the terrorist group Hamas are not only driving protests against Israel’s military offensive in Gaza after the Oct. 7 attack, they've infiltrated American K-12 schools and universities, the liberal media, the cultural elite and the U.S. Army.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific claims made by Project Esther about antisemitism, which is relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: (Yes, the famously Marxist-Hamas U.S. Army ― one of Project 2025’s suggested reforms: “Audit the course offerings at military academies to remove Marxist indoctrination.”)
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a sarcastic commentary on the claims made by Project Esther, which adds context to the article's discussion.

annotations.paragraph: It’s a matter of existential urgency, Project Esther’s authors write, to “extirpate” this antisemitic web from U.S. society (that means “destroy completely”) by canceling visas, upping deportations, revoking university funding, reshaping academic curricula and marginalizing dissent.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the actions proposed by Project Esther, which is directly relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Fighting antisemitism is unquestionably a worthy goal. But in Project Esther, antisemitism, as one Jewish activist described it, is a “smokescreen” for a modern take on McCarthyism, labeling legal immigrants and American-born citizens terrorist sympathizers and marginalizing them accordingly.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers critical commentary on Project Esther, which is relevant to understanding its implications.

annotations.paragraph: Like Project 2025, it makes no secret about what to expect: continued attacks on colleges and universities and America's identity as a nation of immigrants, further erosion of civil rights, due process and the rule of law ― which Jewish people I spoke to say is likely to place Jews in greater danger.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the potential consequences of Project Esther, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: And Project Esther seems to have been constructed without the input of Jewish people or groups. While the Heritage Foundation claims that prominent Jewish organizations worked on Project Esther, when the publication Jewish Insider asked, the Jewish organizations and other groups Heritage named as partners denied the connection. That’s where this gets really weird — Project Esther aligns most closely with evangelical Christians who believe Israel is important not as a Jewish homeland, but because of the role it plays in the Rapture.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides important context about the lack of Jewish input and the unusual alliances behind Project Esther.

annotations.paragraph: I know, I know. But stick with me, we'll get to all of it.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a filler and does not contribute new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: Because Project Esther’s essential premise is not actually true, its authors have to get creative.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a critical perspective on the validity of Project Esther's premise.

annotations.paragraph: Project Esther calls for the creation of a National Task Force to Combat Antisemitism, and invents from whole cloth two classifications, “Hamas Support Networks” and “Hamas Support Organizations," into which nearly anyone can be assigned.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces specific proposals and classifications created by Project Esther.

annotations.paragraph: Like college professors and students, and an "an active cabal of Jew-haters, Israel-haters, and America-haters in Washington" ― which seems to have included President Joe Biden, favorite right-wing targets U.S. Rep. Rashida Tlaib, U.S. Reps. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Pramila Jayapal, but also U.S. Sens. Chuck Schumer and Bernie Sanders (both Jewish, with positions the authors find "both notorious and inexplicable") and U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren.
annotations.reason: This paragraph lists individuals and groups targeted by Project Esther, providing context on its scope.

annotations.paragraph: And pro-Palestinian protesters, of course ― Project Esther’s authors claim that it is impossible to voice support for Palestinians and opposition to Israel’s military offensive without supporting Hamas, despite polls that show only 30% to 40% of Palestinians in the Palestinian Territories say they support Hamas.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses the controversial stance of Project Esther regarding pro-Palestinian protesters.

annotations.paragraph: Project Esther's authors speculate that “complacent” American Jews "may be blind and deaf to the manifestation of HSN-inspired antisemitism at home," or simply in "disbelief." Regardless, the authors conclude, American Jews have "not demonstrated a unified resolve against the HSN, its HSOs and their program of Jew-hatred and America-hatred."
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into the authors' views on American Jews' response to antisemitism.

annotations.paragraph: While antisemitism is rising, this is hardly the way to combat it, said Howard Lupovitch, director of Wayne State University’s Cohn-Haddow Center for Judaic Studies.
annotations.reason: The paragraph introduces a relevant perspective on combating antisemitism.

annotations.paragraph: "For the last 30 years of the 20th century, American Jews had the luxury of levels of antisemitism going down, and the luxury to think that trend was going to continue and that sympathy in the post-Holocaust world would confine it to margins of society and extreme voices," Lupovitch said. "It's only in the 21st century that American Jews have had to confront antisemitism in extreme forms ... When there’s a president who encourages violence, whose rhetoric is stoking this, who thrives on chaos, that did not help."
annotations.reason: This provides historical context and commentary on the rise of antisemitism, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Political chaos, historically, has not served Jewish populations well.
annotations.reason: This is a general statement without specific context or new information.

annotations.paragraph: “The rule of law is by definition not only good for Jews, but necessary for all minorities,” Lupovitch said. “Anything that’s going to undermine the rule of law is going to be bad for Jews, even if the people doing it, in the short term, are offering some kind of immediate gain. The erosion of the rule of law, society becoming more violent … even if Jews are not the target, eventually it reaches the Jews. I can’t think of a single exception to that.”
annotations.reason: This provides relevant commentary on the implications of political actions on Jewish communities.

annotations.paragraph: Project Esther’s assertion of complacency, said Lisa Tencer of Detroit Jews for Justice, ancestors fled pogroms in the USSR in the first part of the 19th Century, “is very insulting, it’s very paternalistic … and it’s infuriating as a Jewish person who has been thinking about antisemitism for a long time.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct response to Project Esther, relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: The Heritage Foundation calls out left-wing antisemitism, like that espoused by some members of the protest movement, Lupavitch said, but ignores antisemitism on the right.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific commentary on the Heritage Foundation's selective focus on antisemitism, which is relevant to the article's premise.

annotations.paragraph: Like the 2017 Unite the Right rally, which President Donald Trump described as including some “very fine people”; the coded antisemitism of QAnon and the Proud Boys; the Tree of Life shooting in Pittsburgh; Musk’s apparent Nazi salutes, his exhortation to Germans for the nation to move past its post-World War II cultural self-examination and his eugenics-inflected approach to fatherhood; or the indelible fact that incidents of antisemitism rise during times of political polarization.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides examples of right-wing antisemitism, which supports the article's discussion on the Heritage Foundation's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Tencer said Project Esther is “smokescreen antisemitism” ― using the pretext of combatting antisemitism to increase racialized fear and division and to further authoritarianism.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a critical perspective on Project Esther, directly related to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: The document’s Hamas Support Networks and Hamas Support Organizations, Tencer said, are just one step of smokescreen antisemitism: “You have to create this confusion by blaming progressives, people of color, Muslims, while claiming to be the true defenders of Jews. It is this machine people are utilizing to create that division and fear and for their own power and gain.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph elaborates on the critique of Project Esther, providing context and examples relevant to the article's argument.

annotations.paragraph: Divided communities, Tencer said, can’t organize.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers a general statement that does not add new information to the article's main argument.

annotations.paragraph: "It’s the same machine that’s used to blame Black and brown people, and Muslims and the LGBTQ+ community,” she said. “First from recognizing that our struggles are connected, and that if one of us isn’t safe and free, none of us are, that antisemitism is distinct but connected to these forms of discrimination, and that the way we fight back is the core of our organization, building partnerships across distances.”
annotations.reason: The paragraph discusses the interconnectedness of antisemitism with other forms of discrimination, which is relevant to the topic of addressing antisemitism.

annotations.paragraph: Lupovitch noted that a frequent target of Heritage Foundation ire is billionaire George Soros, a Jewish Holocaust survivor who spends copiously to support liberal and progressive causes. The conservative thinktank has dubbed Soros a “first-order threat” to American democracy: “I think this is sometimes lost on right-wing Jews," Lupovitch said. "An attack on Soros, even if his politics are different than yours, is an attack on you.”
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific commentary on the Heritage Foundation's stance towards a prominent Jewish figure, which is directly relevant to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: Among some Jews, Lupovitch said, there's the sense that a person or organization that supports Israel cannot be antisemitic. But that's not so: “The next novel form of antisemitism will be the pro-Zionist antisemite. It’s a hard concept for people to grasp, a hard concept for Jews to grasp, because it’s a hard thing to wrap your head around."
annotations.reason: The paragraph introduces a complex idea about antisemitism that challenges common perceptions, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Which brings us back to evangelical Christians, and the Heritage Foundation.
annotations.reason: This sentence serves as a transition without providing new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: In a 2018 poll, 80% of evangelical Christians said their support for Israel was linked to end-times prophecies. Christian evangelicals tell pollsters they value Israel either because of a Biblical instruction to pay deference to the Jewish homeland, or because the Book of Revelation designates the presence of Jewish people in Israel as one condition for Jesus' second coming.
annotations.reason: The paragraph provides context on evangelical Christian support for Israel, which is relevant to understanding the broader discussion of antisemitism and alliances.

annotations.paragraph: “I think many don’t realize the heart of this evangelical support isn’t driven by the protection of Jews, but is self-serving in that it’s trying to bring about the Rapture,” Lupovitch said, who noted that he doesn’t believe all, or even most, evangelicals are antisemitic.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a relevant quote and perspective on evangelical support and its implications for Jewish people.

annotations.paragraph: And that takes us to a very strange place.
annotations.reason: This sentence is vague and does not provide any new information or context.

annotations.paragraph: When I was a teenager knocking around the mall in Mobile, Alabama with my pals ― there wasn’t an awful lot to do in my hometown ― we’d occasionally get proselytized by fundamentalist Christians looking for unbelievers to convert.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a personal anecdote that does not directly relate to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Sometimes, if you got really lucky, they’d hand you a Jack Chick tract, one of those little comic books predicting death or mutilation for kids who drank, used drugs, played Dungeons & Dragons, listened to heavy metal or failed to accept Jesus Christ as their lord and savior. Nor was Jack Chick particularly fond of gay people, Catholics or women’s rights.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides background on Jack Chick tracts but does not directly relate to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: But the tract I found the most intriguing was one detailing the events leading up to the Rapture. The world would be engulfed in despair, corruption, immorality and perversion; the Antichrist would seize political power, creating a one-world government ruled from the Vatican, leading posthaste to the Mark of the Beast, the destruction of Israel, Armageddon, the Rapture and the Second Coming, the Lake of Fire, and so on.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes the content of a tract but does not directly contribute to the main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Raised Presbyterian, a denomination more analytic than impassioned, I was fascinated by both the fervor and credulity of Jack Chick’s fundamentalist Christianity. Who, I wondered ― already jaded at 16 ― could be so naïve as to believe this nonsense?
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a personal anecdote unrelated to the main topic of Jewish people and antisemitism.

annotations.paragraph: Well.
